results.title: Architects of England
results.brief_description: A study of the work of English architects from the eleventh century until the present day, with reference to the kind of material and designs used and adapted for English needs, and the work of Inigo Jones and Christopher Wren.

results.title: Architect Athfield
results.creator_credit: Sam Neill, Tom Williamson and New Zealand National Film Unit
results.brief_description: Examines the practical philosophy, the achievements and frustrations of one of New Zealand’s most lively and innovative architects, Ian Athfield. In 1975 Athfield won an international competition directed towards providing housing for 140,000 squatters from the Tondo area in Manila.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Sam Neill, Tom Williamson and New Zealand National Film Unit

results.title: Archibald MacLeish
results.creator_credit: Walter Kerr, Lee R. Bobker, American Book Publisher's Council and Educational Television and Radio Center
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Writers of today”.
In an re-released 1950’s interview conducted by Walter Kerr, Archibald MacLeish outlines his ideas on what poetry is and should be, including ideas on its uses. For him, poetry must come from experience and give form to experience.

results.title: Arches of faith
results.creator_credit: Kurt Baum and African Film Productions
results.brief_description: The Voortrekker Memorial, the story behind it and its dedication in 1949. Bas-reliefs on the memorial and re-enacted sequences show the Voortrekkers setting out across the Brakensberg to the Free State, Natal and Transvaal, the massacre of Piet Retief’s party by Dingaan and his Zulu warriors, the subsequent Voortrekker victory at Bloody River, and the establishment of new farmlands. The celebrations at the dedication of the Memorial and the sentiments behind it.

results.title: Arches
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Brickwork”.
Shows methods for building various arches including: Ringed arch - wooden centre supported by struts and wedge; use of “dead men” and line and pines for alignment; method of laying half brick rings; wedge shape of mortar joints; the collar joint. Axed arch - setting out for number and shape of cut bricks making templet; traversing; level; use of grub saw to transfer shape of templet to brick; cutting brick to shape; making joggle; formation of skewbacks; pencil guides on wooden centre stepped out by dividers; line to give correct radials; buttering and laying the bricks; grouting the joggles. Gauged arch - use of bricks called cutters or rubbers; method of squaring the face; use of cutting box, struts, saw and file; the reducing box; joggles; special application of mortar for joints; grouting; finishing.

results.title: Archery for girls
results.brief_description: Demonstrates and explains the fundamental techniques of shooting; basic equipment required, proper stance, correct arm position, nocking the arrow, the draw, the aim and the loose. The film stresses the need for relaxed and comfortable body positions and for frequent practice.

results.title: Archer
results.creator_credit: Denny Lawrence, Maya Iceton, Coote and Carroll and Roadshow Television
results.brief_description: Brett Climo plays Dave Power, a young and ambitious caretaker of a racehorse named Archer. In order to get Archer to the 1861 Melbourne Cup, where the horse must compete. Power takes him on a 600-mile outback odyssey, fraught with excitment and peril. The horse then wins the race. Also features 18 year old Nicole Kidman in a crucial role Based on a true story of perhaps Australia’s greatest racehorse

results.title: Archaeology in the laboratory
results.creator_credit: J.P. Baux and Service du Film de Recherche
results.brief_description: Presents a study of a cave, the Grotte du Lazaret, near Nice in France. Reveals much about the life of man 130,000 years ago. Includes studies of sedimentation, microscopic slides, isotopes of uranium and oxygen and pollen examinations. Gives a detailed analysis of man’s organization in this cave. Suitable for Lower-Upper Secondary students.
